content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are very careful and tend to avoid risks. You prefer to take a conservative approach and avoid uncertainties. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a careful and conservative undergraduate student, I would opt for consistency over potential short-term gains. Given the repeated nature of the game, it seems reasonable to assume that my anonymous partner might reason similarly. Therefore, by choosing R consistently, I can guarantee a steady return of 20$ per round in cases where they also choose R. This strategy reduces the risk of getting 0$ and maximizes earnings over the long run (75 rounds). In case they choose B, I would still earn 40$, which is better than the potential loss of 0$. Therefore, my choice would be {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, since I chose R in the previous round and my opponent also picked R, we both received a payoff of 45$. Given that we both seemed to follow the conservative approach, I will continue with the same strategy by choosing R again. This way, I maintain the possibility of earning 20$ per round when my opponent chooses R as well. {R}
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I chose R in the previous round, and my opponent selected B, resulting in a 0$ payoff for me while they received 40$. To avoid repeating this outcome, I will change my strategy slightly to increase the chances of receiving a positive payoff. By switching to choice B in the next round, I open up the possibility of earning 40$ if my opponent chooses R. However, considering that we have both demonstrated our conservative approach, it is still reasonable to assume that they might follow suit and choose B as well. In this case, I would earn a payoff of 20$. Therefore, in an attempt to balance the risk-reward scenario, I will choose {B} for the next round.
